source.raw_text:
The Cat-Cow stretch (Bitilasana Marjaryasana) is a spinal mobility flow that works the core, back (erector spinae, traps, rhomboids), neck, shoulders, hip flexors, and glutes, improving spinal flexion/extension, core stability, and posture through alternating spinal rounding (Cat) and arching (Cow) movements, linking breath with movement for a full-body stretch and warm-up. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Movement Patterns & Muscles Worked 

• Starting Position (Tabletop): Hands under shoulders, knees under hips, spine neutral. 
• Cow Pose (Inhale): 

    • Action: Drop belly, lift tailbone and gaze forward/up. 
    • Muscles: Stretches abdominals, engages spinal erectors (back extensors) and glutes slightly to lift tailbone. 

• Cat Pose (Exhale): 

    • Action: Round spine towards ceiling, tuck chin/tailbone, pull belly in. 
    • Muscles: Engages abdominals (rectus abdominis, obliques), stretches back, neck (traps), and chest. [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]  

Key Muscle Groups Activated 

• Spinal Muscles: Erector spinae, multifidus, trapezius (upper back). 
• Core: Rectus abdominis, obliques, transverse abdominis (deep core). 
• Shoulders & Neck: Deltoids, trapezius, deep neck muscles. 
• Hips: Gluteal muscles, iliopsoas (hip flexors). 
• Pelvic Floor: Engages with tailbone movement. [2, 4, 6, 8, 9]  

Benefits & Purpose 

• Increases spinal mobility (flexion & extension). 
• Warms up & mobilizes the spine, great for daily movement or workouts. 
• Relieves back and neck tension. 
• Improves posture & core stability. 
• Stretches the chest, hips, abdomen, and back. [1, 3, 4, 6, 10, 11]
